Sprain of left ankle, unspecified ligament, subsequent encounter
Sprain of left ankle, unspecified ligament, subsequent encounter

paragraph.content: Cumming, James R, PT - 02/26/2019 9:15 AM CST

item.paragraph:
Brace
- continue to wear continuously for another 3-4 weeks
- wean after that, then wear when you will be on uneven ground a lot, probably for the next 6 months to a year
Exercises
- work on big / exaggerated alphabet, 1-2 x day
- seated, foot planted, slide foot back, keep heel down, till a bit of a stretch in lower part of calf, x 10 sec hold, x 4-5 , 1-2 x day
- heel raises holding counter for support, use left leg a bit more than right, 2 x to fatigue, 3-4 x week
Balance
- most important long term exercise
- start with right foot on volleyball/soccer ball for instance
- some progression ideas: move head side to side, eyes closed, standing on pillow, moving other leg / reaching, ball toss
Gait
- get back to treadmills , 5-10 min bouts 1-2 x day
- progress gradually from there
- stairs - work on standing on left leg on slight elevation, touching ground with right foot and coming right back up
Electronically signed by James R Cumming, PT at 02/26/2019 10:10 AM CST

item.caption: Cumming, James R, PT - 02/26/2019 9:15 AM CST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note might be different from the original.
UW Health Rehabiliation
Physical Therapy Initial Evaluation
UW Health West Clinic
Diagnosis: ankle sprain
PCP: Puneet S Dhillon, MD
Referring provider: No Referring Provider, *
Start of Care: 2/26/2019
SUBJECTIVE
History of Present Condition:
Joshua Craig Mandel is a 36 year old year old male who presents for evaluation of ankle sprain
he describes the onset of symptoms as: fall - on ice/ sprain - inversion sprain
Date of Onset: 2/8/2019 date of injury
Symptoms:
Symptom location: anterolateral ankel
Symptom quality: sharp, aching
Symptom frequency: intermittent, present daily but <50% of the time
Aggravating factors: certain movements (sheet moving across foot in righ way turning in inward), walking
Alleviating factors: rest/ time off feet
Pain ratings:
Pain Score: 0 - No Pain Pain Loc: Ankle
BEST Pain Score: 0 - No Pain
WORST Pain Score: 5/10 Number Scale (some brief pain higher than that)
Since the onset date noted above (new injury or exacerbation), symptoms are gradually improving.
Region Specific Questions (Knee, Leg, Ankle and Foot)
· Mechanical symptoms?: popping at time of incident only , also states some catching at times while walking
Prior History of this Condition and Past and Current Management
Prior history of the same, similar, or related condition and prior management:
no previous history
Health Care Provider and Self Management of condition (past and current):
Urgent care visit day of injury
Prior physical therapy for current episode?: none
Imaging and other diagnostic tests performed:
See imaging section of medical record for more information regarding recent diagnostic work including: Radiographs 2/8/2019
Social History and Activities:
Occupation: work from home for Microsoft, does a lot of travel about 1/3 of the time
Living environment: Joshua currently lives in a House. he currently lives with a partner. At discharge it is planned that same as current
Critical work duties/tasks which are affected by this condition:
self imposted restrictions and/or modification of work duties: not using treadmill work station
Exercise/Activity History: walking - has not done due to injury
Functional Limitations:
Level of function prior to onset of this condition: No prior limitations, able to perform ADLs, IADLs, and general mobility tasks without symptoms or difficulty
The patient reports the following current primary functional limitations due to this condition:
1. Walking - household and community distances
2. stairs
Durable medical equipment currently needed for this condition: has ankle ASO
See assessment below for complete list of activities limitations and participation restrictions due to this condition.
The following patient reported questionnaires were completed for today's visit:
Assigned post visit
OBJECTIVE
Observation: mild swelling, very faint bruising observed lateral foot
Gait:
Level Ground: antalgic, short stance time left
Stairs:walks step to down stairs, able to walk step over step but with deviations / pain
Proprioception/balance: single leg stance on involved leg left impaired: increased sway, hold approx 20 sec
Ankle ROM (Passive unless otherwise specified)
Involved Left Uninvolved Right
Dorsiflexion 18 some end range pain full
Plantarflexion 48 55
Inversion 40 40
Eversion NT NT
Special Tests:
Positive tests include:squeeze test tib-fib compression
Negative tests include:anterior drawer, talar tilt for deltoid ligament, talar tilt for calcaneofibular ligament, posterior drawer, ankle inv/PF end range
Treatment Provided: The patient was educated on the findings of the evaluation and the course for treatment.
Home exercise program, education, and other recommendataions
see patient instructions for complete HEP
Written descriptions of home recommendations and exercises were provided via Patient Instructions
In clinic treatment
HEP instruction and education as detailed in patient instructions
Education on WB progression as well
Tolerance or reaction to treatment:
Appeared to or stated an understanding of the rationale of the intervention and participated with no adverse reaction. In clinic response: no immediate effect
After visit summary: The patient was offered and declined the After Visit Summary paperwork, but is aware of its availability in MyChart.
Total Treatment Time: 50 minutes.
Timed Code Treatment Minutes: 24
Detailed Treatment Times: 26 minutes of Evaluation, 12 minutes of Therapeutic Exercise, 7 minutes of Neuromuscular Reeducation and 8 min gait
Supplies issued to patient in today's visit: None
**The patient is aware that insurance may not cover the above issued item and verbally agreed to the charge.
ASSESSMENT
Overall clinical impression: Joshua Craig Mandel is a 36 year old year old male presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with s/p left ligamentous sprain, inversion, with elements of high ankle sprain as well. Overall severity of sprain is mild to moderate. He has mild limitations in ROM, gait, and proprioception. Today's focus was on prescription of a complete HEP with progressions for ongoing self management with HEP only.
Is physical therapy indicated? Yes
Determination of Evaluation Complexity:
History:
Personal and environmental factors which may impede functional recovery include:none
Relevant PMH: no relevant past medical history
Examination:
Today's examination included the following elements in Body Structure and Function: pain, joint range of motion, joint integrity/structure , gait
Activity Limitations and Participation Restrictions due to this condition: Walking community distances, Walking on different surfaces
Presentation:
Characteristics of the clinical presentation as assessed today is described as: evolving clinical presentation with changing characteristics (moderate), evolving presentation due to the following factors: acuity.
Complexity determination:
Based on personal factors involved, systems assessed, characteristics of the clinical presentation, and level of clinical decision making required the complexity of the evaluation performed today is determined to be: low complexity
Further assessment:
Rehabilitation potential is excellent.
GOALS: to be achieved by 6 weeks
1. Ambulate on uneven surfaces such as grass without reports of instability and minimal increase in pain
2. Walk community distances with 75% less pain
3. Independently ascend/descend steps with 75% less pain
Explanation of need for skilled care:
Mr.Mandel presents with functional limitations and impairments that would benefit from skilled Physical Therapy services in an outpatient setting in order to reduce symptoms in the context of functional activities, improve functional abilities, maximize their level of independence and achieve the established goals for this episode of care. Education was provided that physical therapy may include performance of a home exercise program; recommendations for behavioral modification, suggestions for lifestyle accommodation, recommendations for resuming life roles; and/or development of techniques for self-management where appropriate. Education included the expectation and importance of active participation in order to obtain the most benefit from the services provided. Joshua indicated a willingness to actively participate in rehabilitation and has expressed or demonstrated an understanding of his role.
Barriers to learning and learning preferences were reviewed and documented in the medical record: yes
PLAN
Visit frequency: consultation only, f/u prn
Estimated total number of visits: 1
Interventions most likely to be used include: Therapeutic Exercise - 97110 and Neuromuscular Re-education - 97112.
Plan for next treatment session: NA
Recommended Referrals:
No additional referrals are recommended at this time.
Once patient no longer needs skilled care, a self directed, independent program will be the primary means of management (if needed).
The Goals and Plan of Care were discussed with the patient and agreed upon.The anticipated risks and benefits were discussed with the patient for all treatment options as a component of the elements of informed consent. Consent was obtained verbally and by patient signing the supplied consent form.
Mr. Mandel was encouraged to contact me via MyChart or telephone with any questions or concerns that arise regarding the above assessment or plan of care.
James R Cumming, PT
Electronically signed by James R Cumming, PT at 02/26/2019 11:22 AM CST
